comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Oh, I see the one on the left breaking the smoking ban! Call the authorities quick!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Might be easier to divine the location from Tillbrook's exterior shot. Personally I've no idea. (And "Patrick Sullivan" is hardly a rare name for a rural publican :) )

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: It reminded me (no idea why though) of the old Harp lager advert on Ulster TV with the vikings who land and enter a bar where the barmaid is actress Vicky Michelle -in the days long before she became known as Yvette in 'Allo 'Allo. Their line was "This place has changed....you never used to see women in Irish bars". Now that's one that's not on youtube!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: I always loved the message in the Harp advert, which is borne out by this photo, that historically it is only recently that women would be seen in Irish pubs! In my childhood in Belfast in the 60's my mother wouldnt go into a pub alone!

comment.author: 71592450@N00
comment._content: Wouldnt know the pub but you guarentee they are all dead from Cirrhosis of the liver....

comment.author: 76509678@N04
comment._content: I remember the as bring on the telly over here in England as well. Harp had been released over here and they were keen to push it.

comment.author: 76509678@N04
comment._content: Sorry for the bad grammar there, just getting used to a new on -screen keyboard. I remember the ad being on telly, I meant to say!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/76509678@N04] And did Harp ever do well in England in the end?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: I only remember ever seeing Harp a few times on mainland. Bought a case/tray of it at Makro once but never saw it again! I think the odd Irish bar may have sold but not not the themed Irish pubs.

comment.author: 76509678@N04
comment._content: It wasn't sold much on draft, but was very popular in the canned form.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
And then it disappeared! 

Funny it made me think of Guinness's "New Guinness Light" which was a direct attack on Harp and which used the slogan "They Said It Couldn't Be Done" and they had this gigantic poster site on York Street Belfast to which someone added in spray paint "....and they were right!" It was horrible and Guinness ended up pouring thousands of gallons down the drains!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Love that: "... and they were right"!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64848937@N00
comment._content: Magnificent!  My grandad would have described these kind of 'aul fellas' as the sort that would be 'leppin' like young bucks'.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Classy "aul fellas" suits WITH wellies! "Boys o boys!"
